Award.AwardTitle: 2020 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) - Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference; Rio Grande, Puerto Rico; January 2-6, 2020

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award will support participant travel costs for the 2020 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES)-Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference being held at the Wyndham Rio Grande Resort in Puerto Rico, from January 2-6, 2020. Funds will be used to support travel awards for 12 student/postdoc fellows and 8 junior faculty, selected based on submission of a research abstract for presentation at the meeting. Networking opportunities for the awardees with leaders in the field of cellular and molecular bioengineering will be provided. The meeting will also highlight the research in this field being conducted at the University of Puerto Rico.

The conference program includes podium sessions with keynote and topical invited speakers, including both women and members of underrepresented groups. The primary objective of the meeting is to broaden the boundaries of current capabilities in cell and molecular bioengineering through pursuit of fundamental research, development of novel techniques and biological models, and translation of these discoveries into real-world technology and medical applications. The conference will introduce and integrate a diverse group of engineers and basic scientists possessing clinical and/or entrepreneurial experience. Invited speakers and keynotes will discuss how they bridge the gap between fundamental research and translation in their specific fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to seek funding for travel awards for graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculties (Rising Stars) for the 2020 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) - Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering (CMBE) Conference and to enhance the diversity of speakers at the conference from groups typically underrepresented in STEM. The theme of the 2020 conference is ‘Vision 2020: Emerging Technologies to Elucidate the Rules of Life’. The choice of theme is intended to address the key problem of how the new emerging technologies can help us to engineer better biological systems to transform our understanding of rule of life, as well as translate new discoveries in ways that ultimately benefit human health. We successfully organized the 2020 CMBE conference which accomplished these goals. The outcome of the conference is the increased technology sharing amongst researchers, as well as a new vision and strategic plan for engineering biological systems for basic science and clinical translation.

 

Project outcomes: This conference fulfilled its mission of executing an outstanding CMBE Conference, allowing for a 4-day conference with sessions focused on the theme of Emerging Technologies to Elucidate the Rules of Life. Overall, the conference was a great success. The conference drew 140 attendees, including 7 funded students/postdocs and 8 rising stars junior faculties.

 

Intellectual Merit: This meeting brought together the best thinkers in the field of CMBE to discuss fundamental science and engineering, as well as translational challenges in cellular molecular bioengineering, fostering much discussion and debate. The program featured three new events that were integral to the success of the conference (an educational outreach for underrepresented minority students, a grant writing workshop, and a panel discussion on biological systems engineering & translation.

 

Boarder Impact: This funding allowed for 15 trainees and/or young investigators to attend the meeting through travel awards and rising star awards, including participation in formal and informal career development opportunities. This funding also broaden the participation of local students from University of Puerto Rico with free registration and hotel accommodations. Importantly, 48% of the awardees, 43% of keynote speakers and 53% of invited speakers were from groups underrepresented in STEM including women.
